questionListItems.title: In applying for a Design Organisation Approval (DOA) or Product Organisation Approval (POA), the organisation must nominate a Quality Manager. What qualifications must the Quality Manager possess?

answer.body:
The Quality Manager should be a senior staff who has the responsibility for internal quality assurance. He should have direct access to the accountable manager on matters affecting safety. This person should also meet the following additional requirements: 


(a) possess knowledge of appropriate Singapore aviation legislation, which may be demonstrated by passing the CAAS' examination papers on Airworthiness Administration (L11) or Aviation Legislation (M10) or by attending L11 or M10 courses conducted by an approved maintenance training organisation; and

 

(b) have a minimum of two years of experience in quality assurance or equivalent; and

 

(c) have at least two years of relevant production experience*.

* Note: (c) is only applicable to Quality Managers for SAR-21 approved production organisations.

questionListItems.title: What is the estimated application processing time in obtaining a Design Organisation Approval (DOA) or Product Organisation Approval (POA) certificate?

answer.body: The typical processing time is not more than four (4) months. This includes the time taken to assess where the applying organisation would need to demonstrate compliance with SAR-21 requirements. The processing time is dependent on the quality comprehensiveness of the documents submitted. More information on this can be found in Information Circular “IC 05/17” .

questionListItems.title: How do I apply for a Design Organisation Approval (DOA) or Production Organisation Approval (POA)?

answer.body: You may apply for a Singapore Airworthiness Requirement Part 21 (SAR-21) DOA or POA through CAAS’ Enterprise Safety Oversight System (eSOMS) portal. Information on the conditions and requirements for the respective applications can be found on the eSOMS portal as well.

questionListItems.title: Is it mandatory to register aircraft operating in Singapore with CAAS?

answer.body: It is not mandatory for aircraft/helicopters to be operated in Singapore airspace to be registered in Singapore. However, the aircraft/helicopter must be registered with an International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) Contracting State and have a valid Certificate of Airworthiness.

questionListItems.title: Where can I find the list of Singapore-registered aircraft and their operators?

answer.body:
The list of Singapore-registered (civil) aircraft and their operators, which is updated on a monthly basis, can be found here.

Note: Civil aircraft refer to non-military aircraft.

questionListItems.title: Who is eligible to register an aircraft in Singapore and what are the procedures and documents required for the registration process?

answer.body:
An applicant registering an aircraft in Singapore must satisfy the eligibility criteria stated in the Air Navigation Order (ANO) paragraph 4, which states that:

1) Any previous registration of the aircraft outside Singapore shall cease upon the aircraft being registered in Singapore.

2) The owner of the aircraft belongs to one of the following categories:

  • a. the Singapore Government;

  • b. citizens of Singapore;

  • c. citizens of any Commonwealth country; and

  • d. bodies incorporated in Singapore or in some part of the Commonwealth and having their principal place of business in some part of the Commonwealth.

The cost to register an aircraft can be found in the ANO 12th Schedule paragraph 1, which states the registration fee to be $55 for aircraft with maximum total weight not exceeding 3,000 kg. For aircraft exceeding 3,000 kg, a flat fee of $55 plus $6.60 per 1,000 kg or part thereoff in excess of 3,000 kg applies.

Applications shall be made on Form CAAS(AW) 39 accompanied by particulars and evidence relating to the aircraft and its ownership and submitted to:

Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore
Flight Standards Division
Singapore Changi Airport
P O Box 1
Singapore 918141

questionListItems.title: How will I know if I have been medically cleared by the Civil Aviation Medical Board (CAMB)?

answer.body: You will receive a medical clearance letter from CAMB in your ELMeRS account under the “Documents” tab in your Profile section, which could also state any restrictions or provisos that are imposed with the new Medical Assessment status.

topics.title: Medical Assessment for Flight Crew and ATC

questionListItems.title: Do I have to pay CAAS for the Aeromedical Review process?

answer.body: No, CAAS does not levy an additional fee for processing the Aeromedical Review. However, your DME would charge a professional fee for conducting the Aeromedical Review for you.

topics.title: Medical Assessment for Flight Crew and ATC

questionListItems.title: How do I apply for reinstatement of medical fitness upon the resolution and stabilisation of my medical condition or event?

answer.body: You will be required to visit a DME for an Aeromedical Review to be conducted. With the relevant submitted medical records and medical examination, the DME can then submit a recommendation to CAMB for an assessment.

topics.title: Medical Assessment for Flight Crew and ATC

questionListItems.title: When and where can I report Decrease in Medical Fitness (DMF) to CAAS?

answer.body: You should report your DMF status as soon as possible and prior to undergoing any medical treatment. To report DMF, log in to your ELMeRS account and go to “Notification of Decrease in Medical Fitness”. You will receive an acknowledgement letter which will include instructions not to exercise the privileges of your CAAS licence, as well as the reinstatement process.

topics.title: Medical Assessment for Flight Crew and ATC

questionListItems.title: I have read the instructions on the Decrease in Medical Fitness (DMF) page but am unsure if I need to notify Civil Aviation Medical Board (CAMB) of my recent medical issue. What should I do?

answer.body: You should visit your DME for a consultation as the DME will be able to advise you accordingly. Meanwhile, you should not exercise the privileges of your licence until you have clarified your doubts with your DME.

topics.title: Medical Assessment for Flight Crew and ATC

questionListItems.title: What is Decrease in Medical Fitness (DMF) and how do I know whether I need to report it?

answer.body: A CAAS licence holder who knows or has reason to believe that his/ her physical condition renders him/her temporarily unfit to perform any of the functions to which his/her licence relates as spelt out in Para 20(7) or Para 62(E) of the Air Navigation Order, will need to report DMF to CAAS.

topics.title: Medical Assessment for Flight Crew and ATC

questionListItems.title: How do I check the outcome of my application for a Medical Assessment?

answer.body: You can monitor your application for a Medical Assessment on the dashboard of your ELMeRS account, under the “Progress Tracker” section.

topics.title: Medical Assessment for Flight Crew and ATC

questionListItems.title: I need to initiate an Aeromedical Review to seek clearance to resume duties. Do I have to pay CAAS for this?

answer.body: No, the CAAS does not levy an additional fee for processing the Aeromedical Review.  However, your DME would be charging a professional fee for conducting the aeromedical review submission for you.

topics.title: Medical Assessment for Flight Crew and ATC

questionListItems.title: Can I get reimbursement for the fee for medical evaluation?

answer.body: The reimbursement will depend on the policy of your prospective/current employer.

topics.title: Medical Assessment for Flight Crew and ATC
